the famous families, with roughly 70 genera
and 1000 species. Gallic acid, a low-molecular-weight phenolic compound
found as a major constituent in P. austroarabica One of the
current trends to protect and improve the activity of
plant extracts and plant-derived active molecules is their encapsulation
into nanoparticles. In this form, the drug is entrapped in a nanoparticle
made of biodegradable and biocompatible polymers. This technique is
reported to increase the physical stability and the photostability
of drugs, control their release, and improve their efficacy both in
vitro and in vivo. Anticancer drugs often cause nephrotoxicity as a
side effect. Excessive
intake of xenobiotics damages the tubules and glomeruli and leads
to renal damage and failure. Methotrexate-induced accumulation of reactive oxygen species
(ROS)
in the kidney leads to renal failure and increased expression of toll-like
receptor (TLR4) by tubular cells. Nuclear factor (erythroid-derived
2)-like 2 (Nrf2) is a transcription
factor that stimulates the production of antioxidant enzymes such
as heme oxygenase 1 (HO-1). Upregulated HO-1 induces antioxidant and
antiapoptotic effects and can scavenge free radicals to a considerable
extent. Since oxidative stress,
inflammation, damage, and repair abnormalities
in renal diseases are closely intertwined with the pathological process
of acute kidney injury (AKI), targeting such mechanisms might provide
effective therapies for AKI. of 1:1, which was found to be a suitable ratio for the formation of
small-sized NPs with uniform size distribution. Allotey-Babington
and colleagues prepared four different ratios containing three types
of poloxamer surfactant and found that formulations containing PCL/Poloxamer
188 ratios of 1:1 and 1:2 produced smaller and more uniform PCL NPs. 2.2.1 Particle Size, Zeta Potential, Entrapment
Efficiency, and Drug Loading The particle size (PS) and polydispersity
index are important characteristics of the prepared NP. The PS of
the prepared gallic acid NPs is 192.1 nm, while for the P. austroarabica One of the most important factors that affects the
stability of the nanoparticle is the zeta potential (ZP), which is
an indication of the surface charge. ZP can prominently influence
the nanoparticle stability in suspension through electrostatic repulsion.
The repulsive forces between the nanoparticles are larger when the
ZP increases, forming a more stable colloidal dispersion with a more
uniform size distribution. For gallic acid, the encapsulation efficiency (EE%) and drug loading
(DL%) were determined as they reflect the ability of the formulated
nanoparticles to encapsulate the drug and their capacity to load the
drug. The EE% and DL% for gallic acid nanoparticles were 80.14 ±
3.52% and 3.82 ± 0.17% respectively. 2.2.2 TEM The morphology of the prepared
gallic acid NPs and extract NPs was studied by transmission electron
microscopy. In Figure 2 TEM images of the prepared
nanoparticles: (A) P.

MTX group, (C) P. austroarabica P. austroarabica n p P. austroarabica P. austroarabica 3 Discussion Methotrexate, one of the
most used anticancer drugs, is largely
excreted by the kidneys, and its induced nephrotoxicity represents
a great challenge. The accumulation of MTX and its metabolites in
renal tubules may lead to kidney damage along with its direct noxious
effect on renal tubules. KIM-1 is a sensitive and specific
urinary biomarker for renal injury.  Treatment with MTX leads to an imbalance of renal antioxidants,
which in turn results in lipid peroxidation, decreased tissue antioxidant
capacity, and depletion of renal glutathione reserves. To further
investigate the effect of MTX on the disruption of antioxidant
balance, the current results showed the downregulation of Nrf2 expression
along with diminished HO-1 levels in MTX control mice compared to
the normal group. Nrf2 plays a vital role in regulating the production
of various cytoprotective genes besides cellular defense against oxidants. Toxic insults and oxidative stress can cause massive tubular
cell
death. In this initial stage, tubular cell death triggers an innate
immune response.  The ROS, NF-κB, pathogen-associated
molecular pattern molecules
(PAMPs), and DAMPs are the major known triggering signals of the NLRP3
inflammasome. Apoptosis can be induced by IL-1β
released in response to
inflammasome activation. Our study also showed a significant decrease
in PPARγ levels
in the MTX control mice relative to those of the NC group. PPAR reduces
the inflammatory response by inhibiting the expression of TLR4, NF-κB,
NLRP3, and IL-1β. Natural compounds, including flavonoids,
polyphenols, and terpenoids,
were reported to have beneficial effects against AKI. P. austroarabica P. austroarabica P.
austroarabica P. austroarabica In this
study, LC-ESI-TOF-MS/MS analysis of the P. austroarabica  Certain
potential drugs have limited availability due to their
high hydrophobicity, low bioavailability, poor in vivo stability,
and probable side effects. In addition, few drugs are kidney-targeted
and small molecules are excreted too quickly to reach therapeutic
concentrations that are useful in damaged kidneys. These problems
hinder the further development of pharmacological treatment of AKI.
An innovative and interesting treatment option for AKI that has the
potential to solve the pharmacological treatment dilemma is nanotherapeutics
based on nanotechnology. The nanosize of natural compounds may offer
several advantages over conventional formulations, including increasing
their solubility and bioavailability as well as improving their efficacy. P. austroarabica P. austroarabica  .  PCL nanoparticles
also proved to be biodegradable, biocompatible,
and of low toxicity. PCL-based materials, including nanoparticles,
have demonstrated excellent cytocompatibility, maintaining high cell
viability, and supporting cell proliferation and differentiation.
Bulcão et al. showed that formulated PCL lipid nanocapsules
showed no signs of clinical toxicity, indicating a high safety profile. Suppression of excessive ROS production
has been shown to have
a nephroprotective effect via suppression of NF-κB and inflammasome
activation. P. austroarabica P. austroarabica In the current study,

as our present study on the nephroprotective effect of P. austroarabica  4 Materials and Methods 4.1 Plant Material The plant sample was
air-dried and ground. The extract was produced by macerating 1.5 kg
of each plant with MeOH (3 L, twice) at room temperature. The extracts
were then refrigerated after being condensed at a lower pressure. 4.2 Metabolomic Profiling by LC/MS/MS High-resolution LC-ESI-TOF-tandem mass spectrometric analysis was
executed as previously mentioned. P. austroarabica 4.3 Preparation of PCL Nanoparticles PCL (molecular weight, 14,000) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich,
St. Louis, USA. Poloxamer 188 was purchased from Alfa Aesar (Lancashire,
United Kingdom). The P. austroarabica P. austroarabica 4.4 Determination of PS and ZP, EE%, and DL% of
the Prepared NPs The mean particle diameter of the prepared
NPs was characterized by a dynamic light scattering technique using
a Zetasizer (Malvern Instruments, Malvern, UK). In brief, the NP dispersions
were diluted in a 1:10 ratio with double distilled water and placed
in a chamber with a light scattering angle of 90° and at room
temperature (25 °C). The ZP was measured by the same instrument
using laser Doppler velocimetry at the same temperature. The gallic
acid loading % and entrapment efficiency % in the nanoparticles were
determined using an indirect method to separate the unbound gallic
acid. In brief, the obtained NP dispersions were centrifuged using
cooling centrifuge (Centurion Ltd. PRO-Research K241R-UK) at 14,000
rpm and 4 °C for 1 h, and the free drug in the supernatant was
quantified using a UV–visible spectrophotometer (Jasco v-630,
produced by Jasco, Tokyo, Japan) at 267 nm. A calibration curve of
gallic acid was plotted with concentrations ranging from 5 to 30 μg/mL
in double distilled water ( R 2 EE % = total gallic acid − free gallic acid in supernatant total gallic acid × 100 DL % = total gallic acid − free gallic acid in supernatant total weight of nanoparticles × 100 4.5 Transmission Electron Microscopy The morphology and shape of the prepared P. autroarabica 4.6 In Vivo Evaluation of the Protective Effects
of P. austroarabica P. autroarabica 4.6.1 Animals Forty-eight adult male
Swiss albino mice weighing 20–30 g were used. Animals were
purchased from the Egyptian Biological Products and Vaccines Organization
(Vacsera, Giza, Egypt). Animals were housed in aluminum cages with
direct sunlight at controlled room temperature (25 ± 3 °C)
with a regular 12:12 h light/dark cycle, normal food, and unlimited
access to water and natural ventilation. The treatment of the experimental
animals was carried out according to the established criteria for
the care and use of laboratory animals and was approved by the Ethics
Committee of the Faculty of Pharmacy, Suez Canal University, Egypt
(code: 202307RA1). 4.6.2 Study Design Following a 2 week
accommodation period, the animals were randomly divided into six groups.
Group 1, which served as the NC group, received an oral vehicle combination
of distilled water and DMSO (2:1) for 10 days. The remaining five
groups received a single i.p. dose of 20 mg/kg MTX to induce renal
damage. P. austroarabica P. austroarabica Figure 12 Summary schematic workflow of the study of
the study methodology.
MDA: malondialdehyde, GSH; glutathione, SOD: superoxide dismutase,
CAT: catalase, TNF-α: tumor necrosis factor-α, IL: interleukin,
PPARγ: peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors gamma, Nrf2:
nuclear factor (erythroid-derived 2)-like 2, HO-1: heme oxygenase
1, KIM-1: kidney injury molecule-1, TLR4: toll-like receptor 4, NF-κB:
nuclear factor-κB, and NLRP3: NLR family pyrin domain containing
3. The statistics show that the blank formulation had no significant
effect on the measured parameters compared to the control group. 4.6.3 Renal Function Markers Mice sera
were analyzed for renal function tests using a colorimetric assay
with urea and creatinine detection kits from Bio-Diagnostic UR2110
and CR1250 (Biodiagnostic, Giza, Egypt), respectively. 4.6.4 Histopathological Evaluation Kidney
tissues were fixed in 4% formaldehyde, dehydrated, embedded in paraffin,
sliced at 5 μm, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), 4.6.5 Oxidative Stress Markers The kidney
homogenates were used to determine the levels of catalase (CAT), superoxide
dismutase (SOD), the nonenzymatic antioxidant glutathione (GSH), and
malondialdehyde (MDA) using ELISA kits (MyBioSource, San Diego, CA,
USA; cat. nos. MBS160589, MBS034842, MBS267424, and MBS741034, respectively). 4.6.6 ELISA Assay of Kidney Injury Molecule-1
(KIM-1), Heme Oxygenase 1 (HO-1), Peroxisome Proliferator-Activated
Receptor Gamma (PPARγ), Tumor Necrosis Factor-α (TNF-α),
Interleukin-1β (IL-1β), and Interleukin-6 (IL-6) The concentrations of KIM-1, HO-1, PPARγ, TNF-α, IL-1β,
and IL-6 were determined in the homogenate samples of kidney tissue
using ELISA kits according to the manufacturer’s instructions
(MyBioSource, San Diego, CA, USA; cat. nos. MBS355399, MBS760394,
MBS2501353, MBS825075, MBS175967, and MBS824703, respectively). 4.6.7 Gene Expression Analysis of Nuclear Factor
(Erythroid-Derived 2)-Like 2 (Nrf2), Nuclear Factor Kappa B (NF-κB),
Toll-like Receptor 4 (TLR4), and NLR Family Pyrin Domain Containing
3 (NLRP3) by Real-Time Quantitative Reverse Transcription Polymerase
Chain Reaction (RT-qPCR) The Qiagen miRNeasy Mini Kit (catalog
no. 217004) (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany) was used to extract the total
RNA from the frozen kidney tissue. The concentration and purity of
extracted RNA were measured using a NanoDrop spectrophotometer (Thermo
Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA) at 260/280 nm. The expression
of Nrf2, NF-κB, TLR4, and NLRP3 was examined in kidney tissue
using the GoTaq 1-Step RT-qPCR technology (Promega, Madison, WI, USA).
The expression of β-actin (endogenous control gene) was also
assessed. The primers are listed in Table 2 Primer Sequences Used in Quantitative

the mean ± standard deviation (SD). One-way analysis of variance
(ANOVA) and the Bonferroni post hoc multiple comparison test were
used to determine significant differences between treatment effects,

in addition to terpenes. The current research revealed for the first
